title: Inversion Detection of Transformer Transient Hot Spot Temperature

authors.name: Yu Quan
affiliations: State Grid Hebei Electric Power Company

authors.name: Gong Ruohan
affiliations: Laboratoire d'Électrotechnique et d'Électronique de Puissance de Lille

authors.name: Gong Ruohan
affiliations: Laboratoire d'Électrotechnique et d'Électronique de Puissance de Lille

abstract: This paper proposes an inversion method to estimate a 10 kV oil-immersed transformer transient hot spot temperature (HST). A set of transient feature quantities which can reflect the load change are proposed, those quantities as well as the real time load rate and feature temperature points on the transformer iron shell are taken as the input parameters of a machine learning model established by support vector regression (SVR), thus to describe their relationships with the transformer transient HST. K-fold cross-validation training method and grid search (GS) parameters optimization method are used to find the optimal parameters of the SVR model, the HST inversion results agree well with the transformer temperature rise test data which are conducted with short circuit method, and the HST inversion results outperform the results obtained with GA-BPNN method. The mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) is 1.66 %, and the maximum temperature difference is 2.93 °C.

Inversion Detection of Transformer Transient Hot
Spot Temperature
JIANGJUN RUAN
 1, (Member, IEEE), YONGQING DENG
1, (Member, IEEE),
YU QUAN2, AND RUOHAN GONG3
1School of Electrical Engineering and Automation, Wuhan University, Wuhan 430072, China
2Wuhan Power Supply Company, State Grid Hubei Electric Power Company, Wuhan 430050, China
3Laboratoire d’Electrotechnique et d’Electronique de Puissance, University of Lille, Arts et Metiers Paris Tech, 59000 Lille, France
Corresponding author: Jiangjun Ruan (ruan308@126.com)
This work was supported in part by the Smart Grid Joint Fund of National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant U2066217.
ABSTRACT This paper proposes an inversion method to estimate a 10 kV oil-immersed transformer
transient hot spot temperature (HST). A set of transient feature quantities which can reﬂect the load change
are proposed, those quantities as well as the real time load rate and feature temperature points on the
transformer iron shell are taken as the input parameters of a machine learning model established by support
vector regression (SVR), thus to describe their relationships with the transformer transient HST. K-fold
cross-validation training method and grid search (GS) parameters optimization method are used to ﬁnd the
optimal parameters of the SVR model, the HST inversion results agree well with the transformer temperature
rise test data which are conducted with short circuit method, and the HST inversion results outperform the
results obtained with GA-BPNN method. The mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) is 1.66 %, and the
maximum temperature difference is 2.93 ◦C.
INDEX TERMS Transient hot spot temperature, oil-immersed transformer, support vector regression.
I. INTRODUCTION
The hot spot temperature (HST) of transformer winding has
an important inﬂuence on the transformer operation life and
load capacity. The continuous monitoring of transformer HST
can conducive to a more accurate control of the load, the real-
ization of the transformer dynamic capacity increase, and the
avoidance of transformer failure due to overheating. Besides,
it is helpful to evaluate the transformer oil paper residual
insulation life and provides reference for the transformer
whole life cycle management [1]. The transformer HST can
be detected by inserting the optical ﬁber temperature sensors
into the positions which are supposed to be the hot spot of
the winding [2], [3], but it is difﬁcult to apply the optical
ﬁber sensors to the transformer in operation; As the struc-
ture and the heat dissipation process of the transformer are
very complicated, the key parameters such as heat capacities
and thermal resistances in the thermal circuit are difﬁcult to
obtain accurately, thus the indirect calculation methods such
as empirical formula [4] and thermal model [5] are difﬁcult to
accurately describe the thermal features of transformer, which
The associate editor coordinating the review of this manuscript and
approving it for publication was Yonghong Peng
.
makes it difﬁcult to accurately obtain the HST of transformer
winding. Therefore, how to obtain the HST accurately and
quickly is of great signiﬁcance to ensure the safe and stable
operation of the transformer.
In order to detect the transformer HST simply and efﬁ-
ciently, it has become the research direction of many scholars
to use artiﬁcial intelligence algorithm to retrieve the HST
according to the transformer operation data. The advantage
of using artiﬁcial intelligence algorithm to detect the trans-
former HST lies in that the factors such as the structure of
transformer, the non-uniformity of material and the inﬂu-
ence of environment condition are directly considered in the
learning process of training samples, and the trained model
can be used in the HST detection of transformer in opera-
tion. Take the load current, ambient temperature as the input
features, the transformer HST or top oil temperature (TOT)
can be detected with artiﬁcial neural network (ANN) [6]–
[9]. In view of the fact that the model provided by IEEE
transformer load guide has a large error in detecting the
HST under overload condition, take the load current, ambient
temperature and TOT as the inputs, V . Galdi and L. Ippolito
detected the HST of a 25 kV A distribution transformer with
radial basis function neural network (RBFN), the accuracy
VOLUME 9, 2021 This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 License. For more information, see https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ 7751
J. Ruanet al.: Inversion Detection of Transformer Transient HST
of the model is evaluated according to the test data and it
outperforms the IEEE empirical formula [10], [11]. Q. He
discussed the feasibility of three different neural network in
the transformer TOT detection, and the results show that the
temporal processing networks can achieve the most accurate
prediction [12]. Fuzzy neural system was also used to detect
the transformer HST, and the fuzzy neural system requires
a less calculation and can achieve a higher accuracy than
the multilayer neural network and RBFN network, besides,
the fuzzy neural system has a better anti-noise ability [13]–
[15]. Taken the load current and TOT as the inputs, L. Ippolito
detected the HST of a distribution transformer with Tagaki-
Sugeno-Kang (TSK) fuzzy model, and the high accuracy of
TSK fuzzy model is veriﬁed by comparing the calculation
results with test data and IEEE empirical formula calculation
results [16]. D. Villacci applied the theory of grey system
to the detection of transformer HST, realized the effective
combination of the IEEE empirical formula and machine
learning algorithm [17].
In addition to the above mentioned intelligent analysis
method, support vector machine model is also used in the
inversion of transformer HST. Support vector regression
(SVR) with gradient descent optimization method was used
to detect the HST of an oil immersed transformer [18]. SVR
method was used to detect the HST in a 750MV A/500kV
power transformer, and it has achieved a good detection result
[19]. SVR method combined with information granulation
was proposed to detect the HST of a 15 MV A ODAF trans-
former, and it outperforms a number of existing thermal
model based methods [20].
The above methods show the effectiveness of artiﬁcial
intelligence algorithm in the calculation of transformer wind-
ing HST, in order to further study the transformer transient
HST calculation method under complex working conditions,
such as under changing load and different ambient wind
speed, in this paper, take an S13-M-100 kV A/10 kV distri-
bution transformer as the research object, the transformer
temperature rise test under various working conditions is
carried out, and the transformer winding HST during the
temperature rise test is obtained with ﬂuorescent optical ﬁber.
At the same time, this paper established a reverse detection
method of transformer winding HST under complex work-
ing conditions. In order to reﬂect the time lag relationship
between the iron shell temperature measurement point and
the winding HST, a set of feature quantities which can reﬂect
the load change are proposed, combined with the temperature
points on the transformer iron shell, those quantities are
proposed as the transient feature quantities of the inversion
model, and the support vector regression (SVR) method is
used to describe the complicated multi-dimensional nonlinear
relationship between the transformer HST and those feature
quantities. Based on the established inversion model, the tran-
sient HST of the transformer can be detected by monitoring
those feature quantities of the transformer. The HST inversion
results obtained with the proposed method agree well with
the transformer temperature rise test data, and the HST inver-
FIGURE 1. Flow chart of transformer transient HST inversion method.
TABLE 1. Basic parameters of transformer.
sion results outperform the results obtained with GA-BPNN
method.
II. INVERSION METHOD OF TRANSFORMER TRANSIENT
HOT SPOT TEMPERATURE
A. TRANSFORMER TRANSIENT HST INVERSION METHOD
In the case of knowing the transformer load and external heat
dissipation conditions, the transformer temperature ﬁeld can
be calculated based on the numerical calculation of trans-
former thermal ﬂuid ﬁeld, which can directly reﬂect the
transformer HST and the temperature distribution of trans-
former iron shell. Contrary to forward model, namely direct
calculation, the inverse model is the process of inferring the
cause from the result, which is deﬁned as the estimation of
parameters inside physical model using measured data [21].
Based on the inversion detection idea, a set of feature tem-
perature points on the transformer iron shell as well as other
important transformer transient quantities which can reﬂect
the transformer load change are proposed as the feature
quantities, the SVR method is used to describe the compli-
cated multi-dimensional nonlinear relationship between the
transformer transient HST and those feature quantities. The
speciﬁc ﬂow chart of transformer transient HST inversion is
shown in Fig. 1.
The inversion method is applied to an S13-M-100
kV A/10 kV distribution transformer to verify the accuracy
of the inversion method, the structure of the transformer is
shown in Fig. 2, and the basic parameters of the transformer
are shown in Table 1.

B. BRIEF INTRODUCTION OF SVR
1) BASIC PRINCIPLE OF SVR
In order to estimate a 10 kV oil-immersed transformer tran-
sient HST. A set of transient feature quantities which can
reﬂect the load change are proposed, those quantities as well
as the transformer real time load rate, feature temperature
points on the transformer iron shell are taken as the input
parameters x of a machine learning model established by
SVR, thus to describe their relationships with the transformer
transient HST y.
SVR is a widely used machine learning algorithm, based
on the structural risk minimization principle, it has a strong
ability in dealing with multi-dimensional non-linear prob-
lems with relatively few samples [22], [23], the establishment
process of SVR model can be simply expressed as follows:
Given a set of training samples (x i,yi), i =1,2,...,N, xi ∈
RN , yi ∈R. A hyperplane can be applied to characterizing the
relationship between x and y, namely f (x) =ω·x +b, where
ω∈RN and b ∈R.
|yi −f (xi)|≤ε, i =1,2,···, N (1)
where ε is the insensitive loss coefﬁcient, xi is the input
parameters, yi is the output parameter, namely the transformer
HST.
For any point (x i,yi) in the training sample set, the distance
to the hyperplane di can be expressed as:
di =|ω ·xi +b −yi|

The LIBSVM toolbox in MATLAB which is developed by
Dr. Chih-Jen Lin in National Taiwan University can be used
to solve the dual problem of SVR model, thus the LIBSVM
toolbox is used to solve the regression problem in this paper
[24].
2) PARAMETERS OPTIMIZATION METHOD
Through the analysis of SVR model with RBF kernel, we can
see that penalty coefﬁcient C and kernel function parameter
γ determine the model generalization ability. In this paper,
K-fold cross-validation training method and grid search (GS)
parameters optimization method are used to ﬁnd the optimal
parameters of the SVR model.
As for the K-fold cross-validation training method, the
original training data is divided into K groups, among which
K-1 groups are used as training samples and the remain-
ing one group is used as the test sample for each training,
the whole training process repeats K times. The average value
of the mean square error (MSE) for the K trials was taken as
the performance indicator of the SVR model [25].
In every training session, the grid search (GS) method is
used to ﬁnd the optimal parameters of C and γ. The basic
principle of grid search method is to divide the search ranges
of C and γ into equidistant grids by a certain step size, and
traverse all of data points in the grids to obtain the optimal
values of C and γ. Speciﬁcally, a grid with 2 dimensions
is formed as follows, ([C 1,C2 ... Cn],[γ1,γ2 ...γ m]), among
them, n, m is the number of the penalty coefﬁcient C and ker-
nel function parameter γ, it will form a data set combination
consisting of n×m data. Each (C , γ) combination in the data
VOLUME 9, 2021 7753
J. Ruanet al.: Inversion Detection of Transformer Transient HST
FIGURE 3. Step function for characterizing load change trend.
set is trained, and the combination with the highest accuracy
will be the optimal parameter of the inversion model.
C. SELECTION OF INVERSION FEATURE QUANTITY
When the load of transformer starts to increase gradually
from no-load, due to the existence of heat capacity of trans-
former oil, it takes a certain time for the heat generated by
the transformer winding to transfer to the iron shell, that
is, the temperature of transformer iron shell temperature
measuring point always reﬂects the temperature of winding
at the previous moment. When the temperature rise of the
transformer tends to be stable, the heat capacity will no longer
work, and the temperature of the iron shell measurement
point and winding will not change. Therefore, how to put
forward the feature quantity which can reﬂect the time lag
relationship between the iron shell temperature measurement
point and the winding is the key to the transformer transient
HST inversion. For this reason, in addition to the real-time
load rate, the following three feature quantities which can
reﬂect the load change are proposed.
1) LOAD SHIFT FACTOR
A step function is used to represent the load change trend,
as shown in Fig. 3. When the load rate increases, the input
signal is set to ‘‘1’’. If the load remains the same, signal ‘‘1’’
stays; When the load rate is reduced, the input signal is set
to ‘‘-1’’, if the load remains the same, the signal ‘‘-1’’ stays.
The load current of the transformer is continuously monitored
during the test, considering the ﬂuctuation of current, when
the effective value of current exceeds 1%, the load is consid-
ered to have changed
2) LOAD DURATION
In order to reﬂect the duration of the load at a certain value,
we established the characteristic function of ‘load duration’,
which is shown in Fig. 4. In detail, from the initial time,
when the load is constant, the timing of the load duration will
continue, when the transformer load rate changes, the timing
will restart from the moment of load rate change.
3) LOAD RATE AT THE PREVIOUS ACQUISITION TIME
It takes a certain time for the heat to transfer from the
transformer winding to the iron shell, which makes the shell
temperature at this time always reﬂect the HST at the previous
FIGURE 4. Characteristic function of load duration.
TABLE 2. Locations of temperature measuring points on the iron shell.
FIGURE 5. Temperature measuring points on the iron shell.
moment. Therefore, in order to better build the mapping
model between the HST and the transformer iron shell tem-
perature, the load rate of the previous acquisition time is
added to the transient inversion as the feature quantity, and
the sampling interval in the inversion is 15 minutes.
In addition to the above three transient feature quantities,
the transformer real time load rate, and 9 temperature measur-
ing points on the iron shell were also selected as the features
of the SVR model. Based on the maximum minimum method
[26], all the features are normalized within the range [0, 1].
The speciﬁc locations of the 9 temperature measuring points
on the iron shell are shown in Table 2 and Fig. 5.
III. TRANSFORMER TEMPERATURE RISE TEST
The oil immersed S13-M-100 kV A/10 kV distribution trans-
former is selected as the test object, and the transformer
temperature rise test under different load conditions and wind
speeds is carried out.
A. TEMPERATURE RISE TEST METHOD
Before the temperature rise test, the transformer no-load and
load tests under rated rate are carried out to obtain the trans-
former total loss under rated condition. The transformer rated
7754 VOLUME 9, 2021
J. Ruanet al.: Inversion Detection of Transformer Transient HST
FIGURE 6. Wiring diagram of short circuit temperature rise test.
FIGURE 7. Fluorescent fiber optic temperature sensor.
no-load loss Pw and load loss Pl is 149.2 W and 1517.3 W
respectively. The transformer temperature rise test is con-
ducted with the short circuit method recommended in IEC
60076-2 [27], and the speciﬁc test wiring diagram is shown
in Fig. 6.
The equation for calculating transformer losses under dif-
ferent load rate Pn is as follows:
Pn =n2 ×Pl +Pw (7)
where n is the transformer load rate; Pl is the load loss at rated
load rate; Pw is the no-load loss at rated load rate.
During the test, two ﬂuorescent optical ﬁber temperature
sensors are installed at the active parts that are expected to
be the hottest points of the transformer windings to measure
the transformer HST, which are respectively arranged at 95%
height of phase B high and low voltage winding oil channel,
and the highest temperature of the optical ﬁber is taken as
the transformer HST. The structure diagram of ﬂuorescent
optical ﬁber temperature sensor is shown in Fig. 7, and the
speciﬁc layout of optical ﬁber temperature sensors in the
winding are shown in Fig. 8 and Fig. 9.
The temperature of the iron shell is very important for the
inversion of the transformer HST. In the test, PT100 ther-
mal resistance temperature sensors are used to monitor the
temperature of the iron shell. According to the iron shell
temperature measurement point positions which are speci-
ﬁed on Table 2, nine temperature measurement points are
arranged on the typical point on the transformer iron shell,
and Fig. 10 shows the actual arrangement of the thermal
resistance temperature sensors.
As shown in Fig. 11, in order to prevent the tempera-
ture measurement accuracy of thermal resistance from being
FIGURE 8. Installation locations of fiber optic temperature sensors.
FIGURE 9. Fiber optic temperature sensors arrangement.
FIGURE 10. Thermal resistance temperature sensor arrangement in the
test.
FIGURE 11. Thermal resistance temperature sensor.
affected by external environmental factors, a heat insulation
layer is laid on the thermal resistance.
In order to consider the inﬂuence of wind speed on the
transformer temperature rise characteristics, fans are used to

FIGURE 12. Transformer wind speed control: (a) Fan, (b) Hand held
anemometer.
FIGURE 13. Winding HST during the first stage.
generate wind of different speeds, and hand held anemometer
was used to measure the wind speed near the transformer.
B. TEMPERATURE RISE TEST RESULTS
In this paper, four stages of transformer temperature rise
test are carried out, the ﬁrst stage and the second stage are
steady state temperature rise test, the load rate of each steady
state test remains unchanged, when the change rate of the
transformer HST is less than 1K/h and lasts for at least 3h,
the transformer load rate can be changed. The ﬁrst and second
stage transformer winding HST are shown in Fig. 13 and
Fig. 14. In the ﬁrst stage, only the change of transformer
load rate is considered, and in the second stage, the effect
of wind speed is also considered. The third stage and the
fourth stage are transformer transient temperature rise tests.
In the third stage, each load lasts for 2 hours, and the wind
speed changes with the load at the same time. In the fourth
stage, each load lasts for 2 hours, and the wind speed in the
environment changes every 1 hour. The third and fourth stage
transformer winding HST are shown in Fig. 15 and Fig. 16.
IV. INVERSION OF TRANSFORMER TRANSIENT HOT SPOT
TEMPERATURE
A. TRAINING AND TEST SAMPLE SELECTION
Six groups of steady-state temperature rise test data with
different load rates are selected as training samples, and the
FIGURE 14. Winding HST during the second stage.
FIGURE 15. Winding HST during the third stage.
FIGURE 16. Winding HST during the fourth stage.
test data in the third stage are also added to the training
samples. The remaining six groups of test data in the steady
state temperature rise test and the transient test data in the
7756 VOLUME 9, 2021
J. Ruanet al.: Inversion Detection of Transformer Transient HST
TABLE 3. Transformer operation conditions of training samples.
TABLE 4. Transformer operation conditions of test samples.
fourth stage are taken as test samples. The speciﬁc training
samples and test samples are shown in Table 3 and Table 4.
The interval time of data sampling is set to 15 minutes,
it is because that the data collected at the interval of 15 min-
utes can reﬂect the change of temperature well and will not
cause the situation of too much data. Therefore, 258 groups
of training samples and 194 groups of test samples were
obtained. Besides, it should be emphasized that in the applica-
tion of this method in the actual transformer HST monitoring,
the appropriate sampling time should be changed according
to the actual load.

C. INVERSION RESULTS OF TRANSFORMER TRANSIENT
HOT SPOT TEMPERATURE
1) HST INVERSION RESULTS WITH GS-SVR METHOD
In the process of parameters optimization, the search range of
penalty coefﬁcient C and kernel function γ is set as [2 3,217]
and[2−20,2−10], the insensitive loss coefﬁcient ε is 10 −2,
and the fold K of the cross validation is 5. The parameters
optimization curve is as shown in Fig. 17, and the speciﬁc
optimization results of kernel function parameters is shown
in Table 5. The mean square error of cross validation between
training samples is 2.23 ×10−4, which shows that the SVR
model of transient samples trained in this paper has a good
performance.
The optimal parameter penalty coefﬁcient C =61147.25
and kernel function parameter γ =9.11 ×10−4 obtained
by GS optimization method are substituted into SVR model
VOLUME 9, 2021 7757
J. Ruanet al.: Inversion Detection of Transformer Transient HST
FIGURE 18. HST inversion results of steady state temperature rise test.
FIGURE 19. HST inversion results of forth stage transient temperature
rise test.
for the HST inversion of the test sample, and the comparison
curve between the HST measured and inversion value are
shown in Fig. 18 and Fig. 19. The inversion error of the test
samples are shown in Fig. 20 and Fig. 21.
The maximum inversion temperature difference is 2.93 ◦C,
and the maximum relative error is 5.58%, which shows that
the inversion value of the HST is in good agreement with the
measured one.
2) HST INVERSION RESULTS COMPARED WITH GA-BPNN
METHOD
Artiﬁcial neural network is also a typical method in trans-
former winding hot spot temperature prediction, using the
same feature quantities and training samples, the predict
results of three layer neural network optimized by genetic
algorithm and support vector machine optimized by the grid
search method are compared.
BPNN is one of feedforward neural networks and widely
used, which adopts the error back propagation algorithm to
adjust weights and thresholds in order to reduce the error
FIGURE 20. Inversion temperature error of test samples.
FIGURE 21. Inversion relative error of test samples.
FIGURE 22. The structure of 3 layer BPNN.
between the output values and the expected values [28].
A three layer BPNN established in the paper is shown
in Fig. 22.
In Fig. 22, xi is the ith input of the input layer. wij is the
weight from the ithneuron of the input layer to the jth neuron
of the hidden layer. wj1 is the weight from the jth neuron of
7758 VOLUME 9, 2021
J. Ruanet al.: Inversion Detection of Transformer Transient HST
FIGURE 23. Genetic algorithm optimized neural network (GA-BPNN).
the hidden layer to the neuron of the output layer. θj is the
threshold of the jth neuron in hidden layer. b1 is the threshold
of neuron in the output layer. φis the activation function of
hidden layer, and the sigmoid activation function is used. 9
is the linear activation function of output layer, and y1 is the
ﬁnal output value [29], [21].
According to the learning process of BPNN, it can be
seen that the weights and thresholds of neurons in hidden
and output layer determine the prediction effect of neural
network, in this paper, genetic algorithm (GA) is used to get
an optimal initial value of neuron weights and thresholds,
the ﬂow of GA-BPNN algorithm is shown in Fig. 23.
The GA-BPNN method is applied to the HST inversion
of test samples, the number of neurons in the input layer is
equal to the number of feature quantities, namely 13(consists
of four feature quantities reﬂect the load change and nine
temperature points on the transformer iron shell), the number
of hidden layer neurons is set to 20. The comparison curve
between the HST measured and inversion value are shown
in Fig. 24, and the inversion error of the test samples are
shown in Fig. 25.
The maximum inversion temperature difference of
194 groups test samples with GA-BPNN method is 5.10 ◦C,
and the maximum relative error is 8.16%. Compared with
GA-BPNN method, the maximum inversion temperature
difference of test samples with GS-SVR method is 2.93 ◦C,
and the maximum relative error is 5.58%, Which proves
that GS-SVR method has a better inversion effect than GA-
BPNN method. The four error indexes comparison of the two
methods are shown in Table 6, which further proves that GS-
SVR method has a better inversion effect.
3) EFFECTIVENESS OF LOAD RELATED FEATURE QUANTITIES
In order to further illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed
feature quantities reﬂecting the transient load variation, only
FIGURE 24. HST inversion results of 194 groups test samples with

take the current real-time load rate and the nine temperature
points on the transformer iron shell as the transient feature
quantities of the GS-SVR inversion model. The comparison
curve between the HST measured and inversion value are
shown in Fig. 26, and the inversion error of the 194 groups test
samples are shown in Fig. 27. The maximum inversion tem-
perature difference of test samples with GA-BPNN method
is 14.33 ◦C, and the maximum relative error is -21.15%.
It can be seen that the proposed feature quantities reﬂecting
load variation can greatly improve the inversion accuracy of
transient HST.

J. Ruanet al.: Inversion Detection of Transformer Transient HST
FIGURE 26. HST inversion results of 194 groups test samples with GS-SVR
method (without the feature quantities reflecting the transient load
variation).
FIGURE 27. Inversion relative error of 194 groups test samples with
GS-SVR method (without the feature quantities reflecting the transient
load variation).
V. CONCLUSION
In this paper, a set of feature temperature points on the trans-
former iron shell as well as other transient quantities which
can reﬂect the load change are proposed as feature quantities,
based on the SVR inversion model, the transient HST of
a 10 kV oil immersed distribution transformer is detected.
The maximum inversion temperature difference is 2.93 ◦C,
and the mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) is 1.66 %,
the inversion value of the transformer transient HST is in
good agreement with the measured one, and it outperform
the result obtained with GA-BPNN method. The inversion
results veriﬁed the feasibility of the real time inversion of oil
immersed transformer transient HST with SVR model.
The inversion method provides a new method for on-line
detection of transformer winding HST. In practical applica-
tion, the transient HST of the transformer can be detected by
monitoring the transformer transient feature quantities, real
time load rate and the temperature of the measuring points on
the iron shell. The research results in this paper can provide
reference for transformer load control.

JIANGJUN RUAN (Member, IEEE) was born
in Zhejiang, China, in 1968. He received the
B.S. and Ph.D. degrees in electric machine engi-
neering from the Huazhong University of Sci-
ence and Technology, Wuhan, China, in 1990 and
1995, respectively. He completed his postdoctoral
research from the Wuhan University of Hydraulic
and Electric Engineering, Wuhan, in 1998. He is
currently a Professor with the School of Electrical
Engineering and Automation, Wuhan University.
His research interests include electromagnetic ﬁeld numerical simulation,
and high voltage and insulation technology.
YONGQING DENG (Member, IEEE) was born
in Jiangxi, China, in 1992. He received the
B.S. degree in electrical engineering and automa-
tion from the School of Electrical Engineering,
Wuhan University, Wuhan, China, in 2016. He
is currently pursuing the Ph.D. degree with the
School of Electrical Engineering and Automation,
Wuhan University. His main research interests
include high voltage and insulation technology,
numerical analysis, and engineering application of
electromagnetic ﬁeld.
YU QUAN was born in Jiangxi, China, in 1995.
She received the master’s degree in electrical engi-
neering from Wuhan University, Wuhan, China,
in 2019. Her research interests include multi-
physical ﬁeld simulation, transformer condition
assessment, high voltage and insulation technol-
ogy, and application of artiﬁcial intelligence algo-
rithm in transformer hot spot prediction.
RUOHAN GONG was born in Jiangxi, China,
in 1991. He received the B.Eng. degree in elec-
tronic technology and the Ph.D. degree in electri-
cal engineering from Wuhan University, Wuhan,
China, in 2012 and 2018, respectively. He is cur-
rently holding a postdoctoral position with the
University of Lille. His current research interests
include multi-physical analysis and deep learning.
